title: An Antarctic Tour of the Tidyverse
text:
readr: info


OverviewCheatsheetReading





Importing data is the very first step!
You can use readr to import rectangular data.

You can import‚Ä¶

comma separated (CSV) files with read_csv()
tab separated files with read_tsv()
general delimited files with read_delim()
fixed width files with read_fwf()
tabular files where columns are separated by white-space with read_table()
web log files with read_log()






 PDF: https://github.com/rstudio/cheatsheets/raw/main/data-import.pdf 








R for Data Science: Ch 11 Data import
Package documentation: https://readr.tidyverse.org/

title: An Antarctic Tour of the Tidyverse
text:
readr: exercise


Read data inSave data


Both options below will get you the same dataset,  try it out!
Option 1: load using URL

read_csv("https://portal.edirepository.org/nis/dataviewer?packageid=knb-lter-pal.219.3&entityid=002f3893385f710df69eeebe893144ff")

 Option 2: load using filepath

read_csv("tutorial/raw_adelie.csv")





Lucky for us, the palmerpenguins üì¶ compiles data from all three species together for us!
penguins contains a clean dataset

penguins <- 
  palmerpenguins::penguins 

head(penguins)
## # A tibble: 6 √ó 8
##   species island    bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_l‚Ä¶¬π body_‚Ä¶¬≤ sex    year
##   <fct>   <fct>              <dbl>         <dbl>       <int>   <int> <fct> <int>
## 1 Adelie  Torgersen           39.1          18.7         181    3750 male   2007
## 2 Adelie  Torgersen           39.5          17.4         186    3800 fema‚Ä¶  2007
## 3 Adelie  Torgersen           40.3          18           195    3250 fema‚Ä¶  2007
## 4 Adelie  Torgersen           NA            NA            NA      NA <NA>   2007
## 5 Adelie  Torgersen           36.7          19.3         193    3450 fema‚Ä¶  2007
## 6 Adelie  Torgersen           39.3          20.6         190    3650 male   2007
## # ‚Ä¶ with abbreviated variable names ¬π‚Äãflipper_length_mm, ¬≤‚Äãbody_mass_g


penguins_raw contains raw data

penguins_raw <- 
  palmerpenguins::penguins_raw

head(penguins_raw)
## # A tibble: 6 √ó 17
##   study‚Ä¶¬π Sampl‚Ä¶¬≤ Species Region Island Stage Indiv‚Ä¶¬≥ Clutc‚Ä¶‚Å¥ `Date Egg` Culme‚Ä¶‚Åµ
##   <chr>     <dbl> <chr>   <chr>  <chr>  <chr> <chr>   <chr>   <date>       <dbl>
## 1 PAL0708       1 Adelie‚Ä¶ Anvers Torge‚Ä¶ Adul‚Ä¶ N1A1    Yes     2007-11-11    39.1
## 2 PAL0708       2 Adelie‚Ä¶ Anvers Torge‚Ä¶ Adul‚Ä¶ N1A2    Yes     2007-11-11    39.5
## 3 PAL0708       3 Adelie‚Ä¶ Anvers Torge‚Ä¶ Adul‚Ä¶ N2A1    Yes     2007-11-16    40.3
## 4 PAL0708       4 Adelie‚Ä¶ Anvers Torge‚Ä¶ Adul‚Ä¶ N2A2    Yes     2007-11-16    NA  
## 5 PAL0708       5 Adelie‚Ä¶ Anvers Torge‚Ä¶ Adul‚Ä¶ N3A1    Yes     2007-11-16    36.7
## 6 PAL0708       6 Adelie‚Ä¶ Anvers Torge‚Ä¶ Adul‚Ä¶ N3A2    Yes     2007-11-16    39.3
## # ‚Ä¶ with 7 more variables: `Culmen Depth (mm)` <dbl>,
## #   `Flipper Length (mm)` <dbl>, `Body Mass (g)` <dbl>, Sex <chr>,
## #   `Delta 15 N (o/oo)` <dbl>, `Delta 13 C (o/oo)` <dbl>, Comments <chr>, and
## #   abbreviated variable names ¬π‚ÄãstudyName, ¬≤‚Äã`Sample Number`, ¬≥‚Äã`Individual ID`,
## #   ‚Å¥‚Äã`Clutch Completion`, ‚Åµ‚Äã`Culmen Length (mm)`

title: Slides | Silvia Canel√≥n
text:
readr: exercise


Read data inSave data


Both options below will get you the same dataset!
Option 1

# option 1: load using URL ----
raw_adelie_url <- read_csv("https://portal.edirepository.org/nis/dataviewer?packageid=knb-lter-pal.219.3&entityid=002f3893385f710df69eeebe893144ff")

Option 2

# option 2: load using filepath ----
raw_adelie_filepath <- read_csv("tutorial/raw_adelie.csv")





Lucky for us, the palmerpenguins üì¶ compiles data from all three species together for us!
penguins contains a clean dataset

penguins <- 
  palmerpenguins::penguins 

head(penguins)
## # A tibble: 6 √ó 8
##   species island    bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_l‚Ä¶¬π body_‚Ä¶¬≤ sex    year
##   <fct>   <fct>              <dbl>         <dbl>       <int>   <int> <fct> <int>
## 1 Adelie  Torgersen           39.1          18.7         181    3750 male   2007
## 2 Adelie  Torgersen           39.5          17.4         186    3800 fema‚Ä¶  2007
## 3 Adelie  Torgersen           40.3          18           195    3250 fema‚Ä¶  2007
## 4 Adelie  Torgersen           NA            NA            NA      NA <NA>   2007
## 5 Adelie  Torgersen           36.7          19.3         193    3450 fema‚Ä¶  2007
## 6 Adelie  Torgersen           39.3          20.6         190    3650 male   2007
## # ‚Ä¶ with abbreviated variable names ¬π‚Äãflipper_length_mm, ¬≤‚Äãbody_mass_g




penguins_raw contains raw data

penguins_raw <- 
  palmerpenguins::penguins_raw

head(penguins_raw)
## # A tibble: 6 √ó 17
##   study‚Ä¶¬π Sampl‚Ä¶¬≤ Species Region Island Stage Indiv‚Ä¶¬≥ Clutc‚Ä¶‚Å¥ `Date Egg` Culme‚Ä¶‚Åµ
##   <chr>     <dbl> <chr>   <chr>  <chr>  <chr> <chr>   <chr>   <date>       <dbl>
## 1 PAL0708       1 Adelie‚Ä¶ Anvers Torge‚Ä¶ Adul‚Ä¶ N1A1    Yes     2007-11-11    39.1
## 2 PAL0708       2 Adelie‚Ä¶ Anvers Torge‚Ä¶ Adul‚Ä¶ N1A2    Yes     2007-11-11    39.5
## 3 PAL0708       3 Adelie‚Ä¶ Anvers Torge‚Ä¶ Adul‚Ä¶ N2A1    Yes     2007-11-16    40.3
## 4 PAL0708       4 Adelie‚Ä¶ Anvers Torge‚Ä¶ Adul‚Ä¶ N2A2    Yes     2007-11-16    NA  
## 5 PAL0708       5 Adelie‚Ä¶ Anvers Torge‚Ä¶ Adul‚Ä¶ N3A1    Yes     2007-11-16    36.7
## 6 PAL0708       6 Adelie‚Ä¶ Anvers Torge‚Ä¶ Adul‚Ä¶ N3A2    Yes     2007-11-16    39.3
## # ‚Ä¶ with 7 more variables: `Culmen Depth (mm)` <dbl>,
## #   `Flipper Length (mm)` <dbl>, `Body Mass (g)` <dbl>, Sex <chr>,
## #   `Delta 15 N (o/oo)` <dbl>, `Delta 13 C (o/oo)` <dbl>, Comments <chr>, and
## #   abbreviated variable names ¬π‚ÄãstudyName, ¬≤‚Äã`Sample Number`, ¬≥‚Äã`Individual ID`,
## #   ‚Å¥‚Äã`Clutch Completion`, ‚Åµ‚Äã`Culmen Length (mm)`

readr: info


OverviewCheatsheetReading





Importing data is the very first step!
You can use readr to import rectangular data.

You can import‚Ä¶

comma separated (CSV) files with read_csv()
tab separated files with read_tsv()
general delimited files with read_delim()
fixed width files with read_fwf()
tabular files where columns are separated by white-space with read_table()
web log files with read_log()






 PDF: https://github.com/rstudio/cheatsheets/blob/main/tidyr.pdf 








R for Data Science: Ch 10 Tibbles
Package documentation: https://tibble.tidyverse.org

title: Slides | Silvia Canel√≥n
text:
tibble: exercise


CodeResultChatMore


Let‚Äôs take a look at the differences!

# try each of these commands in the console and see if 
# you can spot the differences!

as_tibble(penguins)
as.data.frame(penguins)




as_tibble(penguins) |> head(4)

# A tibble: 4 √ó 8
  species island    bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_l‚Ä¶¬π body_‚Ä¶¬≤ sex    year
  <fct>   <fct>              <dbl>         <dbl>       <int>   <int> <fct> <int>
1 Adelie  Torgersen           39.1          18.7         181    3750 male   2007
2 Adelie  Torgersen           39.5          17.4         186    3800 fema‚Ä¶  2007
3 Adelie  Torgersen           40.3          18           195    3250 fema‚Ä¶  2007
4 Adelie  Torgersen           NA            NA            NA      NA <NA>   2007
# ‚Ä¶ with abbreviated variable names ¬π‚Äãflipper_length_mm, ¬≤‚Äãbody_mass_g



as.data.frame(penguins) |> head(4)

  species    island bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
1  Adelie Torgersen           39.1          18.7               181        3750
2  Adelie Torgersen           39.5          17.4               186        3800
3  Adelie Torgersen           40.3          18.0               195        3250
4  Adelie Torgersen             NA            NA                NA          NA
     sex year
1   male 2007
2 female 2007
3 female 2007
4   <NA> 2007




What differences do you see?
You might see a tibble prints:

variable classes
only 10 rows
only as many columns as can fit on the screen
NAs are highlighted in console so they‚Äôre easy to spot (font highlighting and styling in tibble)

Not so much a concern in an R Markdown file, but noticeable in the console.
Print method makes it easier to work with large datasets.


There are a couple of other main differences, namely in subsetting and recycling. Check them out in vignette("tibble")
Try it out!

vignette("tibble")

title: Slides | Silvia Canel√≥n

OverviewCheatsheetReading






A tibble is much like the dataframe in base R, but optimized for use in the Tidyverse.





 PDF: https://github.com/rstudio/cheatsheets/blob/main/tidyr.pdf

Package documentation: https://tibble.tidyverse.org

variable classes
only 10 rows
only as many columns as can fit on the screen

Not so much a concern in an R Markdown file, but noticeable in the console.
Print method makes it easier to work with large datasets.


There are a couple of other main differences, namely in subsetting and recycling. Check them out in vignette("tibble")
Try it out!

title: Slides | Silvia Canel√≥n
text:
ggplot2: info


OverviewCheatsheetReading



Let‚Äôs start by making a simple plot of our data!
ggplot2 uses the ‚ÄúGrammar of Graphics‚Äù and layers graphical components together to create a plot.


 PDF: https://github.com/rstudio/cheatsheets/raw/main/data-visualization-2.1.pdf 








R for Data Science: Ch 3 Data visualization
Package documentation: https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org

title: Slides | Silvia Canel√≥n
text:
ggplot2: exercise


View the dataScatterplotBoxplotBy SpeciesChat


Get a full view of the dataset:

View(penguins)

 Or catch a glimpse:

glimpse(penguins)

Rows: 344
Columns: 8
$ species           <fct> Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adel‚Ä¶
$ island            <fct> Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgerse‚Ä¶
$ bill_length_mm    <dbl> 39.1, 39.5, 40.3, NA, 36.7, 39.3, 38.9, 39.2, 34.1, ‚Ä¶
$ bill_depth_mm     <dbl> 18.7, 17.4, 18.0, NA, 19.3, 20.6, 17.8, 19.6, 18.1, ‚Ä¶
$ flipper_length_mm <int> 181, 186, 195, NA, 193, 190, 181, 195, 193, 190, 186‚Ä¶
$ body_mass_g       <int> 3750, 3800, 3250, NA, 3450, 3650, 3625, 4675, 3475, ‚Ä¶
$ sex               <fct> male, female, female, NA, female, male, female, male‚Ä¶
$ year              <int> 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007‚Ä¶




Let‚Äôs see if body mass varies by penguin sex using geom_point()

ggplot(data = penguins, aes(x = sex, y = body_mass_g)) + 
  geom_point()






Let‚Äôs see if body mass varies by penguin sex, this time with geom_boxplot()

ggplot(data = penguins, aes(x = sex, y = body_mass_g)) +
  geom_boxplot()






Let‚Äôs see if body mass varies by penguin sex, and now fill the boxplots according to penguin species

ggplot(data = penguins, aes(x = sex, y = body_mass_g)) +
  geom_boxplot(aes(fill = species))




What do you notice?


You might see‚Ä¶

Gentoo penguins have higher body mass than Ad√©lie and Chinstrap penguins
Higher body mass among male Gentoo penguins compared to female penguins
Pattern not as discernible when comparing Ad√©lie and Chinstrap penguins
No NAs among Chinstrap penguin data points! sex was available for each observation
